Demolition of Broadway Theatre at S. E. corner of Seventh Avenue and 41st Street.
January 27, 1929.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

Seventh Avenue at S. W. corner of 41st Street, across Broadway Theatre ruin.

February 5, 1929.

P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

Seventh Avenue at N. W. corner of 41st Street.
March 10, 1929.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

Seventh Avenue at N. W. corner of 41st Street, across Broadway Theatre ruin.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.
February 5, 1929.

Seventh Avenue, north from W. 41st Street, towards Times Square. North of 42nd Street this thoroughfare loses it's identity, becoming a portion of Times Square: the buildings on all sides bearing Broadway addresses. The Paramount Building which is prominently shown is an outstanding example of that practice. Note the Hotel Hermitage at the left margin. This structure adjoins the low building at the S.W. corner of 42nd Street. On the opposite corner (N.W.) is the Rialto Theatre. This is soon to be renovated and will present a different external appearance.

May 27, 1935
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr

Seventh Avenue, north from W. 41st Street, towards Times Square. North of 42nd Street this thoroughfare loses it's identity, becoming a portion of Times Square: the buildings on all sides bearing Broadway addresses. The Paramount Building which is prominently shown is an outstanding example of that practice. Note the Hotel Hermitage at the left margin. This structure adjoins the low building at the S.W. corner of 42nd Street. On the opposite corner (N.W.) is the Rialto Theatre. This is soon to be renovated and will present a different external appearance.

May 27, 1935
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr

Seventh Avenue, north from W. 41st Street, towards Times Square. North of 42nd Street this thoroughfare loses its identity, becoming a portion of Times Square: the buildings on all sides bearing Broadway addresses. The Paramount Building which is prominently shown is an outstanding example of that practice. The tower-like structure outlined by the latter, is at the N.W. corner of 42nd Street, and is a portion of the improvements made to the building housing the Rialto Theatre. Opposite same, and partially seen on the right, is the westerly side of the Times Building. At the left, between 41st and 42nd Streets are, the Stanley Theatre (motion picture) and the Hotel Hermitage.

These photostats (negative and positive) are reproductions of original photographs that were discoloring in the files.

November 9, 1936
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr

Seventh Avenue, north from W. 41st Street, towards Times Square. North of 42nd Street this thoroughfare loses its identity, becoming a portion of Times Square: the buildings on all sides bearing Broadway addresses. The Paramount Building which is prominently shown is an outstanding example of that practice. The tower-like structure outlined by the latter, is at the N.W. corner of 42nd Street, and is a portion of the improvements made to the building housing the Rialto Theatre. Opposite same, and partially seen on the right, is the westerly side of the Times Building. At the left, between 41st and 42nd Streets are, the Stanley Theatre (motion picture) and the Hotel Hermitage.

These photostats (negative and positive) are reproductions of original photographs that were discoloring in the files.

November 9, 1936
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr

Seventh Avenue, north from W. 41st Street and viewing towards Times Square, a district that absorbs this thoroughfare, from 42nd to 47th Streets. Prominently shown is the dominant Paramount Building occupying the 43rd to 44th Street frontage. Above same is the Hotel Astor. The old Rialto Theatre is being demolished in View 1. A two story taxpayer, containing stores and a restaurant was erected here. View 2 is taken during the track removal project conducted by the W. P. A. Note the bus that has replaced the street cars.

P. L. Sperr

W. P. A. photo
Five Boroughs Project

July 6, 1935
June 4, 1937

Seventh Avenue, north from W. 41st Street and viewing towards Times Square, a district that absorbs this thoroughfare, from 42nd to 47th Streets. Prominently shown is the dominant Paramount Building occupying the 43rd to 44th Street frontage. Above same is the Hotel Astor. The old Rialto Theatre is being demolished in View 1. A two story taxpayer, containing stores and a restaurant was erected here. View 2 is taken during the track removal project conducted by the W. P. A. Note the bus that has replaced the street cars.

P. L. Sperr
